pick-the-dominant-term-numerator-or-deno.text: Pick the dominant term (numerator or denominator)

when-the-function-dne-but-you-want-to-kn.text: When the function DNE, but you want to know $\pm \infty$.

irrational-functions-can-have-2-differen.text: Irrational functions can have 2 different horizontal asymptotes, so you do two limits: $lim_{x\to \pm \infty}f(x)$.

since-its-a-va-we-cant-define-a-general-.text: Since it's a VA, we can't define a general limit since there is no function that can have $und$ slope.

finding-sign-of-infinity-again-vas-dont-.text: Finding sign of Infinity (Again, VAs don't exist as a general limit)

pageProps.body:
Asymptotes

Horizontal

limx→±∞f(x)=blim_{x\to \pm \infty}f(x) = blimx→±∞​f(x)=b

Pick the dominant term (numerator or denominator)

Order Goes:

  • exe^xex
  • xnx^nxn
  • ln(x)ln(x)ln(x)
  • constconstconst (Not even considered)
  1. If you have a dominant numerator: DNE
  2. If you have a dominant denominator: 1
  3. If you have the same highest power: numeratordenominator\frac{numerator}{denominator}denominatornumerator​.

HA to Infinity

When the function DNE, but you want to know ±∞\pm \infty±∞.

limx→±∞f(x)=±∞lim_{x\to \pm \infty}f(x) = \pm \inftylimx→±∞​f(x)=±∞

  1. Simplify (Only look at dominant terms)
  2. Plug in "BIG"
  3. Determine if it would be even or odd
    • Disregard constants.

Ex limx→∞4−x2x=±∞lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{4-x^2}{x} = \pm \inftylimx→∞​x4−x2​=±∞

limx→∞−x,so−∞lim_{x\to \infty} -{x}, so -\inftylimx→∞​−x,so−∞

Irrational functions can have 2 different horizontal asymptotes, so you do two limits: limx→±∞f(x)lim_{x\to \pm \infty}f(x)limx→±∞​f(x).

VA

limx→a−f(x)=±∞lim_{x\to a-}f(x) = \pm \inftylimx→a−​f(x)=±∞ or limx→a+f(x)=±∞lim_{x\to a+}f(x) = \pm \inftylimx→a+​f(x)=±∞

Since it's a VA, we can't define a general limit since there is no function that can have undundund slope.

  1. Look at the denominator, and find what makes it 0.
  2. f(x)=1x−4f(x) = \frac{1}{x-4}f(x)=x−41​
  3. (x−4)=0(x-4) = 0(x−4)=0, so x=4x=4x=4.
  4. VA at x=4x=4x=4.

Finding sign of Infinity (Again, VAs don't exist as a general limit)

Left Limit

1. limx→4−f(x)=±∞lim_{x\to 4-}f(x) = \pm \inftylimx→4−​f(x)=±∞

  1. Pick a number less than 4 (3.999).
  2. (x−4)=±∞(x-4) = \pm \infty(x−4)=±∞
  3. 3.999−4=−0.0013.999-4 = -0.0013.999−4=−0.001
  4. limx→4−f(x)=−∞lim_{x\to 4-}f(x) = -\inftylimx→4−​f(x)=−∞

Right Limit

1. limx→4+f(x)=±∞lim_{x\to 4+}f(x) = \pm \inftylimx→4+​f(x)=±∞

  1. (x−4)=±∞(x-4) = \pm \infty(x−4)=±∞
  2. Pick a number greater than 4 (4.001).
  3. 4.001−4=0.0014.001-4 = 0.0014.001−4=0.001, so limx→4−f(x)=∞lim_{x\to 4-}f(x) = \inftylimx→4−​f(x)=∞
